data.scheme_name: Existing - 44Ada- Presumptive Taxation Scheme For Assessees Engaged If Eligible Professional
data.benefits:
1. Simplified Taxation 

2. No need of detailed books of accounts 

3. Ease of Filing return 

4. Fixed rate for Income calculation
data.eligibility:
1. Professionals engaged in Legal, Medical, Technical or Accountancy etc. practice. 
  2. The gross receipts or turnover of the taxpayer should not exceed Rs. 50 lakh in a financial year.
data.conditions:
1. Minimum 50% of total gross receipts has to be shown as profits. 

2. Any other expenditure/deduction under Business and profession cannot be claimed.
data.beneficiaries:
To be eligible for Section 44ADA, the taxpayer must meet the following conditions: 

  • Nature of Profession: The taxpayer must be engaged in a profession referred to in section 44AA(1). These include professions like: Legal (e.g., lawyers, legal consultants) Medical (e.g., doctors, dentists) Technical (e.g., architects, engineers, technical consultants) Accountancy (e.g., chartered accountants, cost accountants) Other professions may be added by the government through notifications. 
  • Gross Receipts Limit: The gross receipts or turnover of the taxpayer should not exceed Rs. 50 lakh in a financial year. 
  • Not Applicable to Certain Professions: This scheme does not apply to taxpayers who are engaged in the business of the profession (such as running a consultancy firm or an IT business). It is only for professionals who work individually or with a small team. 
  • Individual, HUF, and Proprietorship: The scheme is available to individuals, Hindu Undivided Families (HUFs), and sole proprietors. It is not available for partnership firms, LLPs, or companies.
data.prerequisites:
Professionals opting for Section 44ADA must adhere to the following conditions: 

  1. Presumptive Taxation: The presumptive income is calculated at 50% of the gross receipts or turnover of the profession. This means that the professional will pay tax on half of their receipts, with the other half assumed to cover expenses. 
  2. No Detailed Books of Accounts: Professionals are not required to maintain books of accounts under Section 44AA (which usually applies to businesses). There is also no need for a tax audit under Section 44AB, unless the gross receipts exceed Rs. 50 lakh. 
  3. No Additional Deductions: Since 50% of the gross receipts is considered the presumptive income, professionals cannot claim any additional expenses as deductions. All business expenses are considered covered by the 50% deemed expense under the presumptive income rule. 
  4. Income Limits: The gross receipts or turnover must not exceed Rs. 50 lakh during the financial year for the scheme to be applicable. If the receipts exceed this limit, the professional must follow regular taxation procedures, including maintaining books and possibly undergoing tax audit. 
  5. Voluntary Option: Professionals who meet the conditions can voluntarily opt for this scheme. If they choose this scheme, they must apply it for all subsequent years, and it will apply to all the professionâ€™s income. No 
  6. Carry Forward of Losses: Losses arising under Section 44ADA cannot be carried forward to subsequent years. If the presumptive income is lower than actual income, the taxpayer cannot claim the difference as a loss in future years.
data.description:
The key benefits of opting for Section 44ADA include: Simplified Taxation: 

  • Presumptive Income: Instead of maintaining detailed accounts of income and expenses, professionals can calculate their income based on a fixed percentage of their total gross receipts or turnover. 
  • Ease of Filing: The tax filing process becomes simpler because professionals need not provide complex records, simplifying tax returns and audits. 
  • Fixed Rate for Income Calculation: Under this section, 50% of the total gross receipts or turnover is deemed as the presumptive income, and the remaining 50% is considered to be the expenses incurred by the taxpayer. For example, if the total income of a professional is Rs. 10,00,000, then Rs. 5,00,000 (50% of Rs. 10,00,000) is treated as the presumptive income, and no further expense claims are necessary. No 
  • Need for Detailed Books of Accounts: Professionals who opt for Section 44ADA are not required to maintain books of accounts as per Section 44AA. They are also not required to get their accounts audited under Section 44AB, unless their income exceeds the threshold for tax audit. 
  • Tax Savings: Since only 50% of the gross receipts is considered taxable income, professionals may benefit from lower taxable income compared to calculating actual profits, especially in cases where actual expenses are lower. No Further Deductions: Since 50% of the gross receipts are considered as income and the remaining 50% is treated as expenses, professionals cannot claim any additional deductions for expenses like office rent, utilities, salaries, etc.
data.how_to_apply: Claim by filing Income Tax Return
data.additional_info:
1. This scheme can be opted by the eligible persons, if the total gross receipts from the profession does not exceed Rs 50 lakhs. During the previous year, if of the total professional fees collected <= 5% is in cash / bearer cheque / bearer bank draft then the above maximum limit will be enhanced to Rs 75 lakhs.

 2. If the person wants to show profits lower than 50% of Gross receipts, then he has to get his books of accounts audited if his income exceeds basic exemption limit.
